## 5.9

### (a)

Since the density must integrate to 1:

$$
1 = \int_0^1 \int_0^{y_2} k(1-y_2) \, dy_1 \, dy_2
= k/6,
$$

so $k = 6$

### (b)

Because $Y_1 \le Y_2$, we split into two regions (drawing a picture is useful):

$$
P(Y_1 \le \tfrac{3}{4},\, Y_2 \ge \tfrac{1}{2})
= \int_{1/2}^1 \int_{1/2}^{1}6(1 - y_2)dy_1dy_2 +  \int_{1/2}^{3/4} \int_{y_1}^{1}6(1 - y_2)dy_2dy_1= \frac{24}{64} + \frac{7}{64}
= \frac{31}{64}.
$$


## 5.11

The area of the triangular region is 1, so with a uniform distribution this is the value of the density function. Again, using geometry (drawing a picture is again useful):

### (a)

$$
P(Y_1 \le \tfrac{3}{4}, Y_2 \le \tfrac{3}{4})
= 1 - P(Y_1 > \tfrac{3}{4}) - P(Y_2 > \tfrac{3}{4})
= 1 - \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{4}\right) - \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)
= \frac{29}{32}.
$$

### (b)

$$
P(Y_1 - Y_2 \ge 0) = P(Y_1 \ge Y_2)
$$
The region specified in this probability statement represents 1/4 of the total region of support, so  $P(Y_1 \ge Y_2)= \frac{1}{4}$.

## 5.25

### (a)

The marginals are: $f_1(y_1) = e^{-y_1}, \quad y_1 > 0,$ and $f_2(y_2) = e^{-y_2}, \quad y_2 > 0.$ These are exponential densities with $\beta = 1$.

### (b)

$$
P(1 < Y_1 < 2.5) = P(1 < Y_2 < 2.5) = e^{-1} - e^{-2.5} = 0.2858
$$

### (c)

Support: $y_2 > 0$.

### (d)

Conditional density:

$$
f(y_1 \mid y_2) = f_1(y_1) = e^{-y_1}, \quad y_1 > 0.
$$

### (e)

Similarly:

$$
f(y_2 \mid y_1) = f_2(y_2) = e^{-y_2}, \quad y_2 > 0.
$$

### (f)

The answers are the same.

### (g)

The probabilities are the same.


## 5.27

### (a)

$$
f_1(y_1) = \int_0^{y_1} 6(1 - y_2) \, dy_2, =3(1 - y_1)^2, 0 \leq y_1 \leq 1
$$

$$
f_2(y_2) = \int_0^{y_2} 6(1 - y_2) \, dy_1, =6y_2(1 - y_2), 0 \leq y_2 \leq 1
$$

### (b)

$$
P(Y_2 \le \tfrac{1}{2} \mid Y_2 \le \tfrac{3}{4}) = \frac{\int_0^{1/2}\int_0^{y_2}6(1-y_2)dy_1dy_2}{\int_0^{3/4}3(1-y_1)^2dy_1}=\frac{32}{63}.
$$

### (c)

$f(y_1|y_2) = 1/y_2, 0 \le y_1 \le y_2 \le 1$.

### (d)

$f(y_2|y_1) = 2(1-y_2)/(1-y_1)^2, 0 \le y_1 \le y_2 \le 1$.

### (e)

From part (d): $f(y_2|1/2)=8(1-y_2),  = 1/2 \leq y_2 \leq 1$. Thus $P(Y_2 \geq 3/4 | Y_1 = 1/2) = 1/4$
